tn.text: The book of Mark begins with the prophet Isaiah's foretelling the coming of John the Baptist who baptizes Jesus.
The author is Mark, also called John Mark, who is the son of one of the several women named Mary mentioned in the four Gospels. He is also the nephew of Barnabas.
This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This is an idiom that means "ahead of you." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here the word "your" refers to Jesus and is singular. When you translate this, use the pronoun "your" because this is a quote from a prophet, and he did not use Jesus' name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This refers to the messenger.
Doing this represents preparing the people for the Lord's arrival. AT: "will prepare the people for your arrival"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The voice of one calling out in the wilderness
tn.text: This can be expressed as a sentence. AT: "The voice of one calling out in the wilderness is heard" or "They hear the sound of someone calling out in the wilderness"

tn.ref: Make ready the way of the Lord ... make his paths straight
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Make ready the way of the Lord
tn.text: "Get the road ready for the Lord." Doing this represents being prepared to hear the Lord's message when he comes. People do this by repenting of their sins. AT: "Prepare to hear the Lord's message when he comes" or "Repent and be ready for the Lord to come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
In these verses the words "he," "him," and "his" refer to John.
Be sure your reader understands that John was the messenger spoken of by the prophet Isaiah in the previous verse.

tn.ref: The whole country of Judea and all the people of Jerusalem
tn.text: This generalization refers to a great number of people, not to every single person. AT: "Many people from Judea and Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: They were baptized by him ... confessing their sins
tn.text: These two actions happened simultaneously. The people were baptized because they repented of their sins. AT: "When they repented of their sins, John baptized them in the Jordan River"
"John proclaimed"

tn.ref: I am not worthy even to stoop down to untie the strap of his sandals
tn.text: John is comparing himself to a servant to show how great Jesus is. AT: "I am not even worthy to do the lowly task of removing his shoes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
At the time Jesus was alive, people wore sandals that were often made of leather and tied to the foot with leather straps.
"bend down"

tn.ref: but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit
tn.text: This metaphor compares John's baptism with water to the future baptism with of the Holy Spirit. This means John's baptism only symbolically cleanses people of their sins. The baptism by the Holy Spirit will truly cleanse people of their sins. If possible, use the word "baptize" in your translation to keep the comparison to John's baptism. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This marks the beginning of a new event in the storyline.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "John baptized him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the Spirit coming down on him like a dove
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) this is a simile, and the Spirit descended upon Jesus like a bird descends from the sky toward the ground or 2) the Spirit literally looked like a dove as he descended upon Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: a voice came out of the heavens
tn.text: This represents God speaking. Sometimes people avoid referring directly to God because they respect him. AT: "God spoke from the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This is an important title for Jesus. The Father calls Jesus his "beloved Son" because of his eternal love for him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
After Jesus' baptism, he is in the wilderness for 40 days and then goes to Galilee to teach and call his disciples.
"drove Jesus out forcefully"
"He stayed in the wilderness"
"40 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"He was among"
"after John was placed in prison." This can be stated in active form. AT: "after they arrested John" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"preaching"
"It is now time"
"Jesus saw Simon and Andrew"

tn.ref: casting a net in the sea
tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "throwing a net into the water to catch fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Follow me" or "Come with me"

tn.ref: I will make you fishers of men
tn.text: This metaphor means Simon and Andrew will teach people God's true message, so others will also follow Jesus. AT: "I will teach you to gather men to me like you gather fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
It can be assumed that this boat belongs to James and John. AT: "in their boat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"repairing the nets"
It may be helpful to state clearly why Jesus called to James and John. AT: "called them to come with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"servants who worked for them"
James and John went with Jesus.
In the town of Capernaum on the Sabbath Jesus teaches in the synagogue. He sends a demon out of a man, which amazes the people in all the nearby area around Galilee.
"arrived at Capernaum"

tn.ref: as someone who has authority and not as the scribes
tn.text: There are words left out in this statement that can be added. AT: "as someone who has authority taught and not as the scribes taught" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: What do we have to do with you, Jesus of Nazareth?
tn.text: The demons ask this rhetorical question meaning there is no reason for Jesus to interfere with them and that they desire him to leave them. AT: "Jesus of Nazareth, leave us alone! There is no reason for you to interfere with us." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Have you come to destroy us?
tn.text: The demons ask this rhetorical question to urge Jesus not to harm them. AT: "Do not destroy us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here the word "him" refers to the demon-possessed man.

tn.ref: while crying out with a loud voice
tn.text: The demon is the one who is crying out, not the man.

tn.ref: they asked each other, "What is this? A new teaching with authority?
tn.text: The people's response can be written with statements instead of rhetorical questions. AT: "they said to each other, "This is amazing! He gives a new teaching, and he speaks with authority!"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "He" refers to Jesus.
After healing the demon-possessed man, Jesus healed Simon's mother-in-law as well as many other people.

tn.ref: Now Simon's mother-in-law was lying sick with a fever
tn.text: in-law was lying sick with a fever** - The word "Now" introduces Simon's mother-in-law to the story and gives background information about her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
It can be shown clearly who healed her. AT: "Jesus healed her of the fever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that food was served. AT: "she provided them with food and drinks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the words "him" and "he" refer to Jesus.

tn.ref: all who were sick or possessed by demons
tn.text: Here the word "all" is a hyperbole and is used to emphasize that a great number of people came. AT: "many who were sick or possessed by demons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: The whole city gathered together at the door
tn.text: Here the word "whole" is a hyperbole used to emphasize the great number of people seeking Jesus. AT: "Many people from that city gathered outside the door" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Jesus takes time to pray in the midst of his time of healing people. He then goes to towns throughout Galilee to preach, heal, and cast out demons.
Here the words "he" and "him" refer to Jesus.
"a place where he could be alone"

tn.ref: Simon and those who were with him
tn.text: Here "him" refers to Simon. Also, those with him include Andrew, James, John, and possibly other people.
The word "Everyone" is a hyperbole used to emphasize that many people were looking for Jesus. AT: "Many people are looking for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Here the words "he" and "I" refer to Jesus.
"We need to go to some other place." Here Jesus uses the word "us" to refer to himself, along with Simon, Andrew, James, and John.

tn.ref: He went throughout all of Galilee
tn.text: The word "throughout" is an exaggeration used to emphasize that Jesus went to many locations during his ministry. AT: "He went to many places in Galilee" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: A leper came to him. He was begging him; he knelt down and said to him
tn.text: "A leper came to Jesus. He knelt down and was begging Jesus and said"

tn.ref: If you are willing, you can make me clean
tn.text: The phrase "to make me clean" is understood from the next phrase. AT: "If you are willing to make me clean, then you can make me clean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"want" or "desire"

In biblical times, a person who had certain skin diseases was considered unclean until the skin was healed enough to no longer be contagious. AT: "you can heal me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the word "moved" is an idiom meaning to feel emotion about another's need. AT: "Having compassion for him, Jesus" or "Jesus felt compassion for the man, so he" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
It may be helpful to state what Jesus is willing to do. AT: "I am willing to make you clean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
The word "him" used here refers to the leper whom Jesus healed.

tn.ref: Be sure to say nothing to anyone
tn.text: "Be sure to not say anything to anyone"

Jesus told the man to show himself to the priest so that the priest could look at his skin to see if his leprosy was really gone. It was required in the law of Moses for a man to present himself to the priest if he had been cleansed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "yourself" here represents the skin of the leper. AT: "show your skin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
It is best to use the pronoun "them," if possible, in your language. Possible meanings are 1) "a testimony to the priests" or 2) "a testimony to the people."
The word "he" refers to the man Jesus healed.
These two phrases share similar meanings and are used together to emphasize that the man told a lot of people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The word "everyone" is a hyperbole, an exaggeration to emphasize a large number of people. AT: "many people he met" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: Jesus could no longer freely enter into any town
tn.text: It is implied that the large crowds prevented Jesus from being able to enter the towns because the crowds made it difficult for him to walk around there. AT: "the crowds prevented Jesus from moving freely in towns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"lonely places" or "places where no one lived" (UDB)
The word "everywhere" is a hyperbole used to emphasize that the people came from many places. AT: "from all over the region" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
